instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3437 with a hot CPU. Fan spins once.
threads.message:
Hi,

That's my first post on this forum, and having big hopes about it ;-)
Kidding...

So I have that 820-3437 board which starts but only get the fan spinning once. Then full blast and I feel that the CPU is getting too fast.
I've the CPU rail PPVVC_S0_CPU which is a stable 1.78V (I was hoping for a higher voltage by a bad regulator or transistors)

I would replace the Bios chip or the clock chip but I will check that first.

However, I have a basic question since I have a few other 820-3437 with burning CPUs... should we assume CPU is dead if it's boiling or is there still hope?

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3437 with a hot CPU. Fan spins once.
threads.message: History, liquid? Inspect corroded resistors/traces around U6100. Also pin 8 of U1950.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3437 with a hot CPU. Fan spins once.
threads.message:
Hi Duke,

Thanks! It was a broken trace between the quartz and the clock chip.
3 cycles fan spin restored and board alive now.

cheers!
